nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates vastly underestimate economic damages from climate change and therefore should not be used to evaluate climate risks or to develop policy

Influential economic estimates (e.g. Nordhaus DICE) predict small damages: about 2.1% of global income at 3 degrees C and 7.9% at 6 degrees C using a quadratic damage function with coefficient a~0.00227
The scientific climate literature identifies multiple tipping elements likely to be triggered this century (some between 0.5-2 degrees C) and potential tipping cascades that can amplify global change

Key methodological errors in economics damage estimates include: (a) neglecting or downweighting climate tipping points, (b) assuming only weather-exposed sectors are affected, (c) using spatial cross-sectional temperature-income relationships as proxies for temporal climate change, and (d) reliance on narrow expert elicitation and calibrated IAMs
The DICE integrated assessment model, due to its economic structure and assumptions, is incapable of generating an economic collapse outcome regardless of damage severity
Nordhaus explicitly calibrated DICE damages using a simple quadratic damage function D(DeltaT) = a * DeltaT^2 (a approx 0.00227 in 2018) and cited literature in a way that downplays tipping risks

IPCC AR5 and subsequent use of studies produced a cluster of small net-impact estimates (some positive small effects at low warming and modest negative effects at higher warming) which were used to calibrate IAM damage functions

Expert elicitation and climate science papers (Lenton et al., Kriegler et al., Cai et al., Steffen et al.) show tipping points, tipping cascades, and that including tipping risks in DICE-like frameworks increases Social Cost of Carbon by large factors

Assumption that only weather-exposed sectors are vulnerable (agriculture, forestry, etc.) leads to omission of manufacturing, services, government and other sectors (representing ~87% of GDP in Nordhaus 1991 breakdown)

Using current spatial correlations between local temperature and income (cross-sectional regressions) to predict future global warming impacts conflates long-run regional adaptation, trade networks, soil/topsoil history, and fundamentally different spatial/temporal climate physics

Expert elicitation exercises used by economists (Nordhaus survey of 19 experts) mixed non-climate experts, generated wide ranges, and produced central estimates much smaller than climate scientists' judgments
CGE and partial-equilibrium enumerative methods inherit the same omissions and often assume market-driven adaptation eliminates much of partial damages, reducing aggregate estimates
DICE is built on the Ramsey growth framework with Cobb-Douglas production, exogenous labor and TFP growth, full employment, saddle-path stability, and abatement treated as a net cost to output

Sensitivity experiments on DICE: increasing damage coefficient by orders of magnitude yields corner solutions (immediate full mitigation) and extreme temporary declines (consumption and capital-to-output ratios fall very low) but model still recoversâ€”model numerics fail only when damages exceed extreme thresholds, illustrating DICE cannot endogenously produce systemic economic collapse

Because economic production in DICE ignores environmental inputs and allows exogenous productivity and full employment, damage calibration and IAMs based on these assumptions understate systemic risks and overstate resilience

Given conceptual, methodological, modelling, and empirical flaws, economists' published empirical damage estimates and IAM calibrations (e.g. DICE, FUND, PAGE) should be rejected for assessing climate risk and informing policy; science-based approaches that include tipping risks and environmental inputs should guide policy
